title: CTRL0000929722 - Transcribed Interview of Robin Vos, (November 30, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
INTERVIEW OF:
ROBIN VOS
Wednesday, November 30, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 3:13 p.m.
Present:
Representatives Schiff and Cheney.
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
PROFESSIONAL STAFF MEMBER
, SENIOR INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL

For the COMMITTEE ON HOUSE ADMINISTRATION:
, COUNSEL
For ROBIN VOS:
EDWARD D. GREIM
PAUL BROTHERS
GRAVES GARRETT LLC

won't be recording the interview.
recording.

My name is
, senior investigative counsel on the staff of the select

This will be a staff-led interview.
to join and ask questions.
present.
Cheney.

Ms. Cheney.

Speaker Vos.
Mr.
Hi.
Good afternoon.
Thanks.

, and

is on the call. _ ,
is in the conference room at the House office building.
Before we get started, I want to go over a few ground rules.
We're conducting the interview via Webex.
We have agreed that the interview
will not be recorded, but there will be an official record of the interview.
being made by the official reporters who are transcribing the interview right now and will
for the duration of the interview.
And that's
For the benefit of the reporters, we need to avoid talking over one another.
So if
you could please wait until each question is complete before you begin your response,
and we'll wait until your response is complete before we start asking our next question so

proper transcription if we're talking over one another.
It's really impossible for the reporters to take down a
The reporters also can't record nonverbal responses, such as shaking or nodding
of your head.
So it's important when you're answering questions that you answer with

For the benefit of the reporter and the record, there may be times when I'll ask

that you do that for us.
We ask you to provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
question is not clear, please ask for clarification.
simply say so.
If the
If you don't know the answer, please
If you need breaks for any reason, for comfort, discuss anything with your

As we explain to all witnesses who appear before the select committee, please

Do you understand everything that we've covered so far?
Speaker Vos.
I do.
Any questions before we begin?
Speaker Vos.
I understand that you have a statement that you'd like to read into
No.
the record before we get started.
Or, Eddie, do you have something you want to add before Speaker Vos reads his

Yes.

This is Mr. Greim.
You know, we're here notwithstanding an ongoing litigation in the Eastern District

of Wisconsin, and we're here without waiver of any of the legal arguments we've made

questions and potentially may raise that if the questions intrude upon that privilege, but

That's all I have.

Thank you,
Great.
And I should have probably done this at the outset, but before you read your

Speaker Vos.
Sure.
My name is Robin Vos, R-o-b-i-n, last name Vos, V, like
Victor, o-s, like Susan.
Great.
Thank you, Speaker Vos.
If you could go ahead.
And whatever information or statement you want to
share before we begin, now is the time.
Speaker Vos.
And good afternoon to those who are joining us.
At the outset, I wanted to lay a little bit of the facts surrounding my
Thank you, Mr.
communications with former President Donald Trump regarding the 2020 Presidential
election.
I first met the President in passing at various political events, like an awful lot of
elected officials do.
In August of 2021, the President invited me to travel with him to a rally he was
hosting in Alabama.
From that time until July of 2022, President Trump and I had
approximately ten sporadic phone calls.
all kinds of different matters, but most likely politics, golf, and things like that.
During these calls the President and I discussed
On occasion, the President would raise the issue of the 2020 Presidential election
and ask about the efforts in Wisconsin.
with general updates on activities of the Wisconsin Assembly and the status of election
reform legislation in our State.
On July 8th of 2022, the Wisconsin Supreme Court issued a ruling concerning the
I listened to the President and provided him
use of advance ballot drop boxes in future Wisconsin elections.
The next day I received a call from President Trump.
He discussed the opinion
and told me we've got to do something about it.
something was that he wanted me to do, and I did not know specifically what action he
was discussing that the President wanted the legislature to take.
I informed President Trump that under the Constitution there was nothing we
could do.
That was the extent of our conversation.
He did not elaborate on what the
The call only lasted approximately
10 minutes, and I have not spoken to President Trump since that time.
So with that, I am happy to answer any questions that you have, and I appreciate
you giving me the opportunity to at least put some of the facts that I know on the official
record.
Great.
Thank you.
Well, we certainly -- that is helpful, and we'll certainly dig in on some of those
issues that you've raised in your statement, and I'll want to ask some more detailed
questions about them.
the interview.
EXAMINATION
But that gives us a good roadmap to follow over the course of
BY
Q
Before we get into those questions, could you just describe very briefly your
sort of educational and career background?
A
Oh, sure.
I was born and raised in Burlington, Wisconsin.
University of Wisconsin-Whitewater.
worked for a Member of Congress for a couple years.
was elected speaker in 2013, and have served in that role ever since.
Q
Assembly?
I worked in the Capitol for about 5 years, left,
Then I left public service, bought my own company, ran for the legislature in 2004,
I went to the
A
So the only elected office that you've held has been the Wisconsin State
I actually was also elected to the Racine County Board of Supervisors for
about a decade, from 1994 to 2004.
Q
Assembly?
And is it correct you're the longest-serving member of the Wisconsin
A
Longest-serving speaker, not the longest-serving member.
Q
Were you on the ballot in 2020?
A
I was.
Q
For State Assembly?
A
Correct.
Q
Did you campaign for President Trump in 2020?
A
I did.
Q
What was the nature of your campaign work or activities on behalf of
President Trump?
A
I was actually a delegate to the Republican National Convention on his behalf
even though, of course, we didn't have the convention.
And like other people running
for office, I put up yard signs, I encouraged people as I went door to door to support the
Republican ticket.
Q
Did you appear at any rallies with the President -- former President?
A
I don't believe so, but I did attend several events where he was at -- he was
present.
one.
More or less traditional campaign activities.
I went to one rally where I was on the stage with him, but that was the only
I don't recall if it was during the 2020 cycle or before.
Any conversations with the former President during the 2020 sort of
Q
campaign cycle?
of 2020, did you have any conversations with President Trump?
A
So, say, from the summer of 2020 through the election in November
Nothing meaningful, other than being at an event in a receiving line where
you shake his hand and say, "Nice to see you," right?
Q
Okay.
Nothing meaningful.
I've seen a photograph -- and we can pull it up if necessary -- I think
it was in connection with the WISN interview, which we'll talk a little bit about.
the context of that piece, they had a photo -- there it is,
screen -- of you with the President.
has brought it up on the
Is that -- that's the two of you, isn't it?
A
Yeah.
Q
And it looks to be on an airplane, like a private plane.
One?
And in
Is that Air Force
A
No, it's not Air Force One.
Q
Do you know when this photograph was taken?
A
It would have been approximately August of 2021.
Q
Okay.
A
Oh, yes.
Q
Okay.
A
No.
Q
How about since?
A
No.
Q
What were the circumstances that led to you traveling or flying with
So after the 20 -- certainly after the 2020 election?
Did you ever -- had you traveled with the President before that?
President Trump in or around August of 2021?
A
I was invited to attend a rally with him in Alabama.
made for me to fly to New Jersey.
took off from.
flew home.
Arrangements were
I boarded the plane at the private airport where it
I rode with him to Alabama, attended the rally, and flew back, and then
Q
Do you know why you were asked to attend the rally in Alabama?
A
I don't specifically, no.
Q
What was the -- this is after the President had left office?
A
Oh, yeah, uh-huh, yep.
Q
What was the nature of the rally?
A
I actually don't know.
Alabama Republican Party.
the country.
Was it on behalf of a political candidate?
My understanding was it was something for the
I believe it was one of his typical rallies that he does around
Q
And you don't know why it was that you were asked to attend with him?
A
No.
I mean, I assume, but I don't know why.
I mean, I have my own idea
why, but I don't know specifically why.
Q
What's your assumption on that?
A
We had started looking into some of the concerns that folks had during the
2020 election cycle with issues that had occurred, and I think they wanted me to give the
President an update on what was occurring.
Q
Who reached out to you to suggest -- or to ask that you attend the rally in
Alabama in August of 2021?
A
I think it was Reince Priebus.
Q
And did you, in fact, give the President -- or, at that point, the former
President -- an update as to the activities that you just referred to?
A
Yes.
Q
What was the nature of that, or what was the status report, or what did you
tell former President Trump regarding the activities in Wisconsin at that time?
A
I had told him about some of the issues that we had discovered.
were accusations of fraudulent ballots that were cast in a nursing home.
concerns that folks had about absentee ballot boxes.
There
There were
Things like that.
We had just begun an investigation in Wisconsin, and I updated him on some of
the things that were occurring.
Let me -- I want to go back in time a bit.
Q
I know in your statement you said that you had a number of contacts with former
President Trump between August of 2021 and July of 2022.
frame between the election and August of 2021.
I want to focus on the time
Did you have any interactions with President Trump in that time frame?
A
No.
Q
So from November 2020 to August 2021?
A
None.
Q
Did you have any interactions with anyone in the Trump administration or
attorneys working on behalf of President Trump in the November 2020 through
August 2021 time frame?
A
Not that I can recall, huh-uh.
Q
So I assume you're generally aware that after the election, on November 3rd
of 2020, but leading into January of 2021, the President and others acting on his behalf
were questioning the legitimacy of the election and taking steps to potentially overturn
the results of the election.
Were you generally aware that those actions or activities were underway?
A
I saw press reports.
Q
And there was a legal team.
Rudy Giuliani was one of the prominent
members of that legal team that was involved in that effort.
Did you ever have any interactions with Mr. Giuliani or anyone acting with him in
that November 2020 to January 2021 time frame?
A
No.
Q
Did anyone on behalf of the President ever contact you in that
November 2020 to January 2021 time frame regarding potential irregularities or fraud
that they believed had taken place in Wisconsin?
A
Not that I recall, no.
Q
When is the first time that you remember having any interactions with either
the former President or anyone acting on his behalf regarding claims of election fraud or
irregularities in Wisconsin in the 2020 election?
A
The first conversation I had with Donald Trump that was anything more
than, as I said, a grip-and-greet, was on that plane in August of 2021.
Q
Okay.
And then how about anyone else acting on his behalf?
Did anyone
prior to August of 2021 ever reach out to you or contact you regarding claims of election
fraud or irregularities in Wisconsin in the 2020 election?
A
Not specifically from the President, no.
I mean, of course, in Wisconsin
there was a great deal of consternation about the election, so it was a fairly normal topic
in the political sphere.
Sure.
But I'm broadening my question.
Q
Understanding that there were a lot of people talking about those issues in that
time frame in your State -- and I understand that you didn't have any conversations with
the former President on those issues -- but how about others working on his behalf?
And I mean formally working on his behalf.
administration, others, other close allies of the President.
So attorneys, members of the
Did any of them reach out to you or talk with you about claims of fraud or
irregularities in the 2020 election?
A
Not those specific claims.
we talk on a fairly regular basis.
conversation.
specifically about this.
I mean, Reince and I lived together in college, so
So, you know, I think that was more of a friendly
So I want to say yes, I speak to Reince fairly often, but it wasn't
Q
Okay.
A
No.
Q
And so I take it then that in that time frame -- and, again, I'm focusing on the
And other than Mr. Priebus, anybody else?
November 2020 to January 2021 time frame -- that you didn't have any discussions with
anyone associated with President Trump regarding potential action that the Wisconsin
Legislature might take with respect to the 2020 election?
A
Not that I recall.
Q
So, again, just to sort of set some context here or be more specific about
what I'm asking about, you may have heard of various efforts that were taken in States
around the country to change the results of the election in those States in that time
frame that I'm referring to.
Are you generally familiar with the fact that such activities were underway or had
taken place?
A
I've read about it afterwards.
Q
Okay.
I didn't really know about it at the time.
So you've read that in Georgia, in Pennsylvania and Michigan and
some other contested States there were efforts made to contact legislators or to take
certain actions by the -- the Trump campaign was urging action by legislatures in those
States, to take some action with respect to the 2020 election.
Were you -- have you become aware of that?
A
Yes.
Q
Were there any such actions that you were aware of in Wisconsin in that
same time frame?
A
Not that I was involved in.
And I think perhaps -- I don't know how other
States organize themselves, but we have a process where the Governor certifies the
election.
And once the election is certified, it's kind of out of our hands.
So I don't know if other States had a different mechanism, but that's why I just -- I
don't recall it.
Q
Okay.
Well, in many other States in which that same mechanism was in
place the Trump campaign or attorneys acting on behalf of President Trump nevertheless
reached out to and had interactions with legislators in an effort to try to have the
legislatures take steps to change the results of the election.
Did that happen in Wisconsin, to your knowledge?
A
I don't recall that, no.
Q
No one reached out to you to ask you to take such measures in the
November to January time frame?
A
Not that I recall.
Q
I'm sure you've also heard or read about efforts in various States to have
alternate slates of electors appointed in connection with the 2020 election.
Were you part of any discussions in the aftermath of the 2020 election to have
alternate slates of electors appointed in Wisconsin?
A
None.
Nope.
Q
Okay.
After January 6th, so this is -- yeah, after January 6th but before
President Biden was inaugurated, so in that 2 weeks in January of 2021, did you have any
interactions with anyone acting on behalf of the Trump campaign or any member of the
Trump administration?
A
Oh, I don't remember.
Q
Okay.
Since the President left office in -- on January 20th of 2021, I
think -- have you described for us the nature, general nature of your interactions with him
since that time?
A
Yes.
Q
So that would be -- the first interaction after that date of January 20th, 2020
[sic], would be your interaction with respect to the Alabama rally in August of 2021.
A
Correct.
Okay.
I want to walk through some of those ten or so sporadic
conversations that you had with the President -- or the former President -- in that sort of
2021-2022 time frame.
But before I do, I want to pause here to see if anyone else on the call has any
questions on these first issues that we've covered.
Ms. Cheney?
Ms. Cheney.
Speaker Vos, thank you for being here today.
You mentioned that Reince Priebus had been the one potentially who connected
Thanks,
you with President Trump to go to this rally.
Speaker Vos.
since we were kids.
reached out to me saying that, "Perhaps it would be a good idea for you to give an update
to President Trump on the good things that you are doing in Wisconsin."
I did.
Ms. Cheney.
Sure.
Can you tell us about that discussion?
As I mentioned before, Reince and I have been friends
We were involved in the Republican Party together.
So Reince
So that's what
And have you had other conversations with Mr. Priebus about the
Wisconsin Presidential results?
Speaker Vos.
You mean in general?
Ms. Cheney.
I mean -- I'm sorry -- the 2020 Presidential election in Wisconsin.
Speaker Vos.
After that time, not many.
We mostly talk about the future.
have been trying to focus on 2022 and beyond and not look backwards.
Ms. Cheney.
Has Mr. Priebus expressed a view to you about efforts to overturn
the results of the 2020 election in Wisconsin?
Speaker Vos.
Not really, no.
We didn't talk about that specifically.
It was
more about the interactions with President Trump and, you know, the opportunity to give
him information to hopefully make sure he's informed about what's happening in
Wisconsin.
Ms. Cheney.
important?
And did Mr. Priebus indicate to you why he thought that was
Speaker Vos.
I think he was doing it to help make sure that my situation was
protected as a friend, because I think there were some who were attempting to
mischaracterize what was happening in Wisconsin, and he wanted to make sure that
potentially wrong information was not being fed to President Trump about what was
happening.
Ms. Cheney.
And can you -- did he -- can you explain a little bit more about the
mischaracterization he was worried about?
Speaker Vos.
Well, I think there were some in Wisconsin who wanted to go a
dramatically different direction than where we were.
investigation, discover if any wrongdoing had occurred, how it could be fixed with
legislation going forward.
I wanted to do a thorough
There were some in Wisconsin that wanted to go backwards and attempt to do
something different in 2020, which I have consistently said is unconstitutionally
impossible.
not have others do it on my behalf, perhaps in error.
And I think he wanted to make sure that I had the chance to tell that and
Ms. Cheney.
Okay.
Speaker Vos.
Thank you.
Thank you.
BY-:
If I could follow up on that a little bit.
Q
Did Mr. Priebus tell you that President Trump was one of the people who was
thinking of -- or wanted to look back and maybe do something to change the 2020
election?
A
No, he never said that to me.
Q
Did he tell you that Mr. Trump was more sympathetic to one side or the
other in that sort of-- that discussion or the debate that you've just described?
A
We never really got into the specifics.
It was much more along the lines of,
"You need to make sure that you're communicating what's happening so others can't
mischaracterize it."
appreciated.
I think it was more a friend watching out for a friend, which I
Q
Him watching out for you --
A
Right.
Q
-- is the way you perceived it?
A
Yes.
Q
So maybe you've touched on this already, but can you describe for us, as
best you recall, the conversations that you had with former President Trump in August
of 2021 regarding what you were doing and what your -- what was happening in
Wisconsin and what your thoughts were about how things should proceed in Wisconsin?
A
We had recently launched an investigation in Wisconsin to try to get at some
of the accusations that folks brought forward as to what did or did not occur in 2020.
We talked about some of the things that we had hoped to bring forward, some of the
accusations that had been brought up, mostly all the ones that were already in the media.
And we just mostly discussed that.
Now, of course, you know, I don't want to characterize where President Trump
was, but, of course, he had a general belief that there were challenges and things done
wrong in Wisconsin.
perceived to be wrong were and hoped that we would look into some of the accusations.
Q
He spent much of the time reiterating what the things that he
Do you recall what the things were that he reiterated or that he shared with
you he felt had gone wrong in Wisconsin in 2020?
A
I think it focused on the general idea of unsecured ballot drop boxes, ballot
harvesting occurring in Wisconsin, and the idea that you had people who were not
allowed to legally cast a ballot.
We had an incident in my own district, as an example, where nursing home
residents fraudulently were given ballots taken out by somebody who was not allowed to
do it on their behalf, things like that, where there were concerns about the laws on the
books in Wisconsin.
Q
Did he tell you why it was that he was continuing to -- I'll use the term
"litigate" in a sort of informal sense -- why he was continuing to pursue or press these
issues 8 months or so after he had left office?
A
My general recollection was he felt like the election was unfair and did not
result in a ballot that could be -- in a result that could be justified, based on his
knowledge.
Q
But did he offer any explanation as to where he felt you were -- he could go
with the information that you were developing in Wisconsin or why it was important to
develop that information?
I think he wanted us to go backwards to try and look and see what we could
A
do about 2020.
unconstitutional and impossible for us to go back to what occurred in 2020 and have any
effect on the result.
I have consistently said we need to look forward, that it's
It's why I prefer to talk about 2022 and 2024 and what could be changed to
correct the problems that we've either discovered or we perceived to be a problem.
Q
Got it.
And did that conversation that you've just described take place in
August of 2021, or are you describing sort of a series of conversations that took place
between then and July of 2022?
A
the time listening.
It was more the series, because in the beginning, of course, I spent most of
President Trump spent most of the time talking.
So that's how
many of our conversations went.
Q
So I want -- but I want to hone in, if I could, on that August 2021
conversation or series of conversations within that trip.
A
Okay.
Q
It sounds as if he shared with you, President -- former President Trump
shared with you concerns about the 2020 election, correct?
A
Correct.
Q
Did he in that conversation share with you what you've described as looking
backwards, the idea that something could or should be done to change the outcome of
the 2020 election?
A
He did talk about the fact that if something was done incorrectly it has to be
fixed.
correctly or incorrectly, which is why we had an investigator hired, to discover whether or
not those things did, in fact, occur.
And I had made the case that we don't know at that point what had been done
Q
What I'm getting at is what it means to "fix" the situation.
You've put
forward very sort of clearly that you perceive fixing means making sure things don't
happen in the future and don't happen again.
seemed to believe that fixing meant changing the result of the 2020 election.
But there's another school or camp that
Am I characterizing correctly sort of this tension that you were experiencing in
that time frame?
A
Again, if I look at it broadly, from people in Wisconsin, that is accurate.
Some people thought that we could go backwards.
supporters of President Trump.
"You need to go back and do X, Y, or Z."
Q
Many of them were vociferous
But I don't recall President Trump specifically saying,
So that's where I was headed.
In that August 2021 interaction or series of
interactions, are you saying that it wasn't clear to you whether President Trump was in
the "looking forward" camp versus the "looking backwards" camp?
A
He did not specifically address that to me.
Obviously, if you look at media
reports and other things, I understand where it seems like he was heading, but he did not
say that to me specifically, like, "This is what you need to do."
Understood.
Ms. Cheney.
Ms. Cheney.
Speaker Vos, could you just tell us what he did say to you?
Speaker Vos.
Thanks,
I don't recall exactly, which is -- I'm trying to give a flavor of what I
remember, you know, over a year ago, which was basically you need to make sure this
investigation happens, you need to see where the truth is, you need to find out the fraud,
you know, along those lines, because I think he generally believed that a large-scale
amount of fraud occurred in Wisconsin.
At that time we hadn't done the due diligence to investigate it in depth, and that's
what I just described to him.
process, which didn't conclude for another 6 months.
Ms. Cheney.
That's why we hired an investigator, we began the
And did he tell you what he thought would happen if you did,
quote, "fix it"?
Speaker Vos.
I think he believed that potentially we could go back and do
something about the 2020 election.
He didn't say it again specifically.
from the media reports.
perhaps something different could happen.
I only know
But that was the implication, that if enough fraud was found,
Ms. Cheney.
And what do you mean "something different could happen"?
Speaker Vos.
As far as the 2020 election, again, I have been clear and reiterated
over and over that we cannot go backwards.
times.
I have said that to the President multiple
We could only look forward.
Ms. Cheney.
But what did he say to you?
SpeakerVos.
When?
Ms. Cheney.
At any point in these discussions, in terms of "fixing this."
Speaker Vos.
So it was an example where you cannot allow fraud to continue,
which is what I would retort back with and say that's why we need to fix the election laws
and make sure that if anything happened in the past it can't be allowed to happen in the
future.
Ms. Cheney.
And did the President suggest to you any evidence for his
assertions that there had been fraud on a wide scale that would change the result of the
election?
Speaker Vos.
It seems that he had watched media reports.
In Wisconsin, we
had some folks who would report on a large number of ballots that were cast at a nursing
home that was illegal.
count that many doubted the way that they were counted and the results that occurred.
We had individuals who brought forward accusations of people who weren't allowed to
legally cast a ballot and others with ballot harvesting occurring in Wisconsin, which is
illegal.
We had issues where we had votes that were cast at a central
So I think there were many charges that were brought forward, and that's why I
reiterated that there were lots of -- there's lots of smoke, but we needed to make sure if
there was actual fire.
Ms. Cheney.
Did you -- were you aware that a number of these charges had
already been litigated in State and Federal court in Wisconsin?
Speaker Vos.
Well, my -- and I'm not a lawyer -- but my understanding is that
many of the efforts to litigate them weren't fact-based.
They were thrown out on it
wasn't the right court, it wasn't the right time, it wasn't the right way to bring the process
forward.
So that's why I think many folks in Wisconsin especially doubted the results, not
because a court had reviewed it, but because of the way that the review had occurred.
Ms. Cheney.
I appreciate that.
